dublin_core.dcvalue: Keetley et al Keetley V Wood A W Spong J And Stough C 2006 Neuropsychological sequelae of digital mobile phone exposure in humans Neuropsychologia 44 1843 1848 report a study into the effects of mobile phones on a variety of cognitive tasks They report that the presence of an active mobile phone reduces performance on some tasks but surprisingly improved performance on others Bonferroni correction of this multi hypothesis exploratory research however reveals that none of the findings reach normally accepted levels of significance The results of the study remain interesting in suggesting hypotheses for further research however care must be taken if making conclusions based on this research
Made available in DSpace on 2020-02-07T13:29:22Z (GMT). No. of bitstreams: 0 Previous issue date: 2007-01-22
Mobile phones are good for you, pUnder0.36! Observations on Keetley, Wood, Spong and Stough (2006).
